title: Topological insulator
content:
{{Short description|State of matter with insulating bulk but conductive boundary}}
{{Use American English|date=January 2019}}{{technical|date=August 2016}}
[[File:Topological insulator informal phase diagram-en.svg|thumb|An (informal) phase diagram with topological insulators, trivial insulators, and conductors. There is no path from the topological insulators to the trivial insulators that does not cross the conducting phase. The diagram depicts a <math>\mathbb{Z}_2</math>topological invariant, since there are two "islands" of insulators.]]
[[File:Topological insulator band structure.svg|thumb|An idealized [[Electronic band structure|band structure]] for a 3D time-reversal symmetric topological insulator. The [[Fermi level]] falls within the bulk band gap which is traversed by topologically-protected spin-textured Dirac surface states.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Moore|first=Joel E.|date=2010|title=The birth of topological insulators|journal=Nature|language=En|volume=464|issue=7286|pages=194–198|doi=10.1038/nature08916|issn=0028-0836|pmid=20220837|bibcode=2010Natur.464..194M|s2cid=1911343}}</ref><ref name="HM">{{Cite journal|last1=Hasan|first1=M.Z. |last2=Moore|first2=J.E.  |date=2011|title=Three-Dimensional Topological Insulators|journal=Annual Review of Condensed Matter Physics|language=En|volume=2|pages=55–78|doi=10.1146/annurev-conmatphys-062910-140432|bibcode=2011ARCMP...2...55H|arxiv=1011.5462|s2cid=11516573 }}</ref>]]
A '''topological insulator''' is a material whose interior behaves as an [[Insulator (electrical)|electrical insulator]] while its surface behaves as an [[Electrical conductivity|electrical conductor]],<ref name="KM">{{Cite journal|last = Kane | first = C. L.  |author2=Mele, E. J.   | year = 2005 | title = Z<sub>2</sub> Topological Order and the Quantum Spin Hall Effect | journal = [[Physical Review Letters]] | volume = 95 | issue = 14 | pages = 146802 | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.95.146802 | pmid = 16241681  | bibcode=2005PhRvL..95n6802K|arxiv = cond-mat/0506581 | s2cid = 1775498 }}</ref> meaning that electrons can only move along the surface of the material.

A topological insulator is an insulator for the same reason a "[[Triviality (mathematics)|trivial]]" (ordinary) insulator is: there exists an [[Band gap|energy gap]] between the [[valence and conduction bands]] of the material. But in a topological insulator, these bands are, in an informal sense, "twisted", relative to a trivial insulator.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Zhu |first1=Zhiyong |last2=Cheng |first2=Yingchun |last3=Schwingenschlögl |first3=Udo |date=2012-06-01 |title=Band inversion mechanism in topological insulators: A guideline for materials design |url=https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.85.235401 |journal=Physical Review B |language=en |volume=85 |issue=23 |pages=235401 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.85.235401 |bibcode=2012PhRvB..85w5401Z |hdl=10754/315777 |issn=1098-0121|hdl-access=free }}</ref> The topological insulator cannot be [[Continuous function|continuously]] transformed into a trivial one without untwisting the bands, which closes the band gap and creates a conducting state. Thus, due to the continuity of the underlying field, the [[Surface state|border]] of a topological insulator with a trivial insulator (including [[vacuum]], which is topologically trivial) is forced to support a conducting state.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal |last1=Qi |first1=Xiao-Liang |last2=Zhang |first2=Shou-Cheng |date=2011-10-14 |title=Topological insulators and superconductors |url=https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/RevModPhys.83.1057 |journal=Reviews of Modern Physics |language=en |volume=83 |issue=4 |pages=1057–1110 |doi=10.1103/RevModPhys.83.1057 |arxiv=1008.2026 |bibcode=2011RvMP...83.1057Q |s2cid=118373714 |issn=0034-6861}}</ref>

Since this results from a global property of the topological insulator's [[Electronic band structure|band structure]], local (symmetry-preserving) perturbations cannot damage this surface state.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal |last1=Hasan |first1=M. Z. |last2=Kane |first2=C. L. |date=2010-11-08 |title=Colloquium: Topological insulators |url=https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/RevModPhys.82.3045 |journal=Reviews of Modern Physics |volume=82 |issue=4 |pages=3045–3067 |doi=10.1103/RevModPhys.82.3045|bibcode=2010RvMP...82.3045H |s2cid=16066223 |arxiv=1002.3895 }}</ref> This is unique to topological insulators: while ordinary insulators can also support conductive surface states, only the surface states of topological insulators have this robustness property.

This leads to a more formal definition of a topological insulator: an insulator which cannot be [[Adiabatic theorem|adiabatically]] transformed into an ordinary insulator without passing through an intermediate conducting state.<ref name=":10" /> In other words, topological insulators and trivial insulators are separate regions in the [[phase diagram]], connected only by conducting phases. In this way, topological insulators provide an example of a [[state of matter]] not described by the [[Landau theory|Landau symmetry-breaking theory]] that defines ordinary states of matter.<ref name=":11" />

The properties of topological insulators and their surface states are highly dependent on both the dimension of the material and its underlying [[Symmetry in quantum mechanics|symmetries]], and can be classified using the so-called [[Periodic table of topological invariants|periodic table of topological insulators]]. Some combinations of dimension and symmetries forbid topological insulators completely.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal |last=Kitaev |first=Alexei |date=2009-05-14 |title=Periodic table for topological insulators and superconductors |url=https://aip.scitation.org/doi/abs/10.1063/1.3149495 |journal=AIP Conference Proceedings |volume=1134 |issue=1 |pages=22–30 |doi=10.1063/1.3149495 |arxiv=0901.2686 |bibcode=2009AIPC.1134...22K |s2cid=14320124 |issn=0094-243X}}</ref> All topological insulators have at least [[U(1)|U(1) symmetry]] from particle number conservation, and often have [[Time reversal symmetry|time-reversal symmetry]] from the absence of a magnetic field. In this way, topological insulators are an example of [[symmetry-protected topological order]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Senthil |first=T. |date=2015-03-01 |title=Symmetry-Protected Topological Phases of Quantum Matter |url=https://www.annualreviews.org/doi/10.1146/annurev-conmatphys-031214-014740 |journal=Annual Review of Condensed Matter Physics |language=en |volume=6 |issue=1 |pages=299–324 |doi=10.1146/annurev-conmatphys-031214-014740 |arxiv=1405.4015 |bibcode=2015ARCMP...6..299S |s2cid=12669555 |issn=1947-5454}}</ref> So-called "topological invariants", taking values in <math>\mathbb{Z}_2</math> or <math>\mathbb{Z}</math>, allow classification of insulators as trivial or topological, and can be computed by various methods.<ref name=":12" />

The surface states of topological insulators can have exotic properties. For example, in time-reversal symmetric 3D topological insulators, surface states have their [[Spin quantum number|spin]] locked at a right-angle to their momentum (spin-momentum locking). At a given energy the only other available electronic states have different spin, so [[Umklapp scattering|"U"-turn scattering]] is strongly suppressed and conduction on the surface is highly metallic.

Despite their origin in quantum mechanical systems, analogues of topological insulators can also be found in classical media. There exist [[Photonic topological insulator|photonic]],<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Khanikaev |first1=Alexander B. |last2=Hossein Mousavi |first2=S. |last3=Tse |first3=Wang-Kong |last4=Kargarian |first4=Mehdi |last5=MacDonald |first5=Allan H. |last6=Shvets |first6=Gennady |date=March 2013 |title=Photonic topological insulators |url=https://www.nature.com/articles/nmat3520 |journal=Nature Materials |language=en |volume=12 |issue=3 |pages=233–239 |doi=10.1038/nmat3520 |pmid=23241532 |arxiv=1204.5700 |bibcode=2013NatMa..12..233K |issn=1476-4660}}</ref> [[Magnetic topological insulators|magnetic]],<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Tokura |first1=Yoshinori |last2=Yasuda |first2=Kenji |last3=Tsukazaki |first3=Atsushi |date=February 2019 |title=Magnetic topological insulators |url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s42254-018-0011-5 |journal=Nature Reviews Physics |language=en |volume=1 |issue=2 |pages=126–143 |doi=10.1038/s42254-018-0011-5 |bibcode=2019NatRP...1..126T |s2cid=53694955 |issn=2522-5820}}</ref> and [[Acoustics|acoustic]]<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=He |first1=Cheng |last2=Ni |first2=Xu |last3=Ge |first3=Hao |last4=Sun |first4=Xiao-Chen |last5=Chen |first5=Yan-Bin |last6=Lu |first6=Ming-Hui |last7=Liu |first7=Xiao-Ping |last8=Chen |first8=Yan-Feng |date=December 2016 |title=Acoustic topological insulator and robust one-way sound transport |url=http://www.nature.com/articles/nphys3867 |journal=Nature Physics |language=en |volume=12 |issue=12 |pages=1124–1129 |doi=10.1038/nphys3867 |arxiv=1512.03273 |bibcode=2016NatPh..12.1124H |s2cid=119255437 |issn=1745-2473}}</ref> topological insulators, among others.

==Prediction==
The first models of 3D topological insulators were proposed by B. A. Volkov and O. A. Pankratov in 1985,<ref name=Volkov85>{{Cite journal|last1=Volkov|first1=B. A.|last2=Pankratov|first2=O. and subsequently by Pankratov, S. V. Pakhomov, and Volkov in 1987.<ref name=Pankratov87>{{Cite journal|last1=Pankratov|first1=O. A.|last2=Pakhomov|first2=S. V.|last3=Volkov|first3=B. Existence of interface Dirac states in HgTe/CdTe was experimentally verified by [[Laurens W. Molenkamp|Lauren W. Molenkamp's]] group in 2D topological insulators in 2007.<ref name="König07">{{Cite journal|last1=König|first1=Markus|last2=Wiedmann|first2=Steffen|last3=Brüne|first3=Christoph|last4=Roth|first4=Andreas|last5=Buhmann|first5=Hartmut|last6=Molenkamp|first6=Laurens W.|last7=Qi|first7=Xiao-Liang|last8=Zhang|first8=Shou-Cheng|date=2007-11-02|title=Quantum Spin Hall Insulator State in HgTe Quantum Wells|url=https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.1148047|journal=Science|language=en|volume=318|issue=5851|pages=766–770|doi=10.1126/science.1148047|issn=0036-8075|pmid=17885096|arxiv=0710.0582|bibcode=2007Sci...318..766K|s2cid=8836690}}</ref>

== Experimental realization ==

'''MBE growth of topological insulators'''

Molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) is an [[epitaxy]] method for the growth of a crystalline material on a crystalline substrate to form an ordered layer.  MBE is performed in [[Vacuum|high vacuum]] or [[ultra-high vacuum]], the elements are heated in different electron beam evaporators until they [[Sublimation (phase transition)|sublime]]. The gaseous elements then condense on the wafer where they react with each other to form [[single crystal]]s.

MBE is an appropriate technique for the growth of high quality single-crystal films.  In order to avoid a huge [[Lattice constant#Lattice matching|lattice mismatch]] and [[Crystallographic defect|defects]] at the interface, the substrate and thin film are expected to have similar lattice constants.  MBE has an advantage over other methods due to the fact that the synthesis is performed in high vacuum hence resulting in less contamination.  Additionally,  lattice defect is reduced due to the ability to influence the growth rate and the ratio of species of source materials present at the substrate interface.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last1=Heremans|first1=Joseph P.|last2=Cava|first2=Robert J.|last3=Samarth|first3=Nitin|date=2017-09-05|title=Tetradymites as thermoelectrics and topological insulators|journal=Nature Reviews Materials|language=En|volume=2|issue=10|pages=17049|doi=10.1038/natrevmats.2017.49|issn=2058-8437|bibcode=2017NatRM...217049H}}</ref> Furthermore,  in MBE,  samples can be grown layer by layer which results in flat surfaces with smooth interface for engineered heterostructures.  Moreover,  MBE synthesis technique benefits from the ease of moving a topological insulator sample from the growth chamber to a characterization chamber such as  angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) or [[Scanning tunneling microscope|scanning tunneling microscopy]] (STM) studies.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://www.wiley.com/en-us/Topological+Insulators:+Fundamentals+and+Perspectives-p-9783527337026|title=Topological Insulators: Fundamentals and Perspectives|date=2015-06-29|website=Wiley.com|language=en-us|access-date=2018-07-29}}</ref>

==PVD growth of topological insulators==

The physical vapor deposition (PVD) technique does not suffer from the disadvantages of the exfoliation method and, at the same time, it is much simpler and cheaper than the fully controlled growth by molecular-beam epitaxy. The PVD method enables a reproducible synthesis of single crystals of various layered quasi-two-dimensional materials including topological insulators (i.e., {{chem|Bi|2|Se|3}}, {{chem|Bi|2|Te|3}}).<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Kong|first1=D.|last2=Dang|first2=W.|last3=Cha|first3=J.J.|last4=Li|first4=H.|last5=Meister|first5=S.|last6=Peng|first6=H. K.|last7=Cui|first7=Y|date=2010|title=SFew-layer nanoplates of {{chem|Bi|2|Se|3}} and {{chem|Bi|2|Te|3}} with highly tunable chemical potential|journal=Nano Letters|language=EN|volume=10|issue=6|pages=2245–50|doi = 10.1021/nl101260j|pmid=20486680|arxiv=1004.1767|bibcode=2010NanoL..10.2245K|s2cid=37687875}}</ref> The resulted single crystals have a well-defined crystallographic orientation; their composition, thickness, size, and the surface density on the desired substrate can be controlled.
The thickness control is particularly important for 3D TIs in which the trivial (bulky) electronic channels usually dominate the transport properties and mask the response of the topological (surface) modes. By reducing the thickness, one lowers the contribution of trivial bulk channels into the total conduction, thus forcing the topological modes to carry the electric current.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Stolyarov|first1=V.S.|last2=Yakovlev|first2=D.S.|last3=Kozlov|first3=S.N.|last4=Skryabina|first4=O.V.|last5=Lvov|first5=D.S.|date=2020|title=Josephson current mediated by ballistic topological states in Bi2Te2.3Se0.7 single nanocrystals|journal=Communications Materials |language=EN|volume=1|issue=1 |page=38| doi = 10.1038/s43246-020-0037-y|bibcode=2020CoMat...1...38S|s2cid=220295733|doi-access=free}} [[File:CC-BY icon.svg|50px]]  Text was copied from this source, which is available under a [https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/  Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License].</ref>

=== Bismuth-based topological insulators===
Thus far, the field of topological insulators has been focused on bismuth and antimony [[chalcogenide]] based materials such as {{chem|Bi|2|Se|3}} , {{chem|Bi|2|Te|3}} , {{chem|Sb|2|Te|3}} or [[Bismuth antimonide|Bi<sub>1 − x</sub>Sb<sub>x</sub>]], Bi<sub>1.1</sub>Sb<sub>0.9</sub>Te<sub>2</sub>S.<ref name="NatureComm"/>  The choice of chalcogenides is related to the van der Waals relaxation of the lattice matching strength which restricts the number of materials and substrates.<ref name=":5" />  Bismuth chalcogenides have been studied extensively for TIs and their applications in [[thermoelectric materials]].  The van der Waals interaction in TIs exhibit important features due to low surface energy.  For instance, the surface of {{chem|link=Bismuth telluride|Bi|2|Te|3}} is usually terminated by Te due to its low surface energy.<ref name=":3" />

Bismuth chalcogenides have been successfully grown on different substrates. In particular, Si has been a good substrate for the successful growth of  {{chem|Bi|2|Te|3}} . However, the use of sapphire as substrate has not been so encouraging due to a large mismatch of about 15%.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last1=Ginley|first1=Theresa P.|last2=Wang|first2=Yong|last3=Law|first3=Stephanie|date=2016-11-23|title=Topological Insulator Film Growth by Molecular Beam Epitaxy: A Review|journal=Crystals|language=en|volume=6|issue=11|pages=154|doi=10.3390/cryst6110154|doi-access=free}}</ref> The selection of appropriate substrate can improve the overall properties of TI. The use of buffer layer can reduce the lattice match hence improving the electrical properties of TI.<ref name=":6" /> {{chem|Bi|2|Se|3}} can be grown on top of various  Bi<sub>2 − x</sub>In<sub>x</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> buffers.  Table 1 shows {{chem|link=Bismuth selenide|Bi|2|Se|3}} , {{chem|Bi|2|Te|3}} , {{chem|link=Antimony telluride|Sb|2|Te|3}}  on different substrates and the resulting lattice mismatch. Generally,  regardless of the substrate used, the resulting films have a textured surface that is characterized by pyramidal single-crystal domains with quintuple-layer steps. The size and relative proportion of these pyramidal domains vary with factors that include film thickness, lattice mismatch with the substrate and interfacial chemistry-dependent film nucleation. The synthesis of thin films have the stoichiometry problem due to the high vapor pressures of the elements. Thus, binary tetradymites are extrinsically doped  as n-type ({{chem|Bi|2|Se|3}} , {{chem|Bi|2|Te|3}} ) or p-type ({{chem|Sb|2|Te|3}} ).<ref name=":5" /> Due to the weak van der Waals bonding, graphene is one of the preferred substrates for TI growth despite the large lattice mismatch.

== Identification==
The first step of topological insulators identification takes place right after synthesis, meaning without breaking the vacuum and moving the sample to an atmosphere. That could be done by using angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) or scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) techniques.<ref name=":7" /> Further measurements includes structural and chemical probes such as X-ray diffraction and energy-dispersive spectroscopy but depending on the sample quality, the lack of sensitivity could remain. Transport measurements cannot uniquely pinpoint the <math>\mathbb{Z}_2</math> topology by definition of the state.

== Classification ==
{{Main articles|Periodic table of topological invariants}}
[[Bloch's theorem]] allows a full characterization of the wave propagation properties of a material by assigning a matrix to each wave vector in the [[Brillouin zone]].

Mathematically, this assignment creates a [[vector bundle]]. Different materials will have different wave propagation properties, and thus different vector bundles. If we consider all insulators (materials with a band gap), this creates a space of vector bundles. It is the topology of this space (modulo trivial bands) from which the "topology" in topological insulators arises.<ref name=":12" />

Specifically, the number of [[Connected component (topology)|connected components]] of the space indicates how many different "islands" of insulators exist amongst the metallic states. Insulators in the connected component containing the vacuum state are identified as "trivial", and all other insulators as "topological". The connected component in which an insulator lies can be identified with a number, referred to as a "topological invariant".<ref name=":12" />

This space can be restricted under the presence of symmetries, changing the resulting topology. Although [[Unitary matrix|unitary]] symmetries are usually significant in quantum mechanics, they have no effect on the topology here.<ref>{{Cite web |title=10 symmetry classes and the periodic table of topological insulators |url=https://topocondmat.org/w8_general/classification.html |access-date=2022-10-11 |website=topocondmat.org}}</ref> Instead, the three symmetries typically considered are time-reversal symmetry, particle-hole symmetry, and chiral symmetry (also called sublattice symmetry). Mathematically, these are represented as, respectively: an [[Antiunitary operator|anti-unitary operator]] which commutes with the [[Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics)|Hamiltonian]]; an anti-unitary operator which [[Anticommutative property|anti-commutes]] with the Hamiltonian; and a unitary operator which anti-commutes with the Hamiltonian. All combinations of the three together with each spatial dimension result in the so-called [[Periodic table of topological invariants|periodic table of topological insulators]].<ref name=":12" />

== Future developments ==
The field of topological insulators still needs to be developed. The best bismuth chalcogenide topological insulators have about 10 meV bandgap variation due to the charge. Further development should focus on the examination of both: the presence of high-symmetry electronic bands and simply synthesized materials. One of the candidates is [[Heusler compound|half-Heusler compounds]].<ref name=":7" /> These crystal structures can consist of a large number of elements. Band structures and energy gaps are very sensitive to the valence configuration; because of the increased likelihood of intersite exchange and disorder, they are also very sensitive to specific crystalline configurations. A nontrivial band structure that exhibits band ordering analogous to that of the known 2D and 3D TI materials was predicted in a variety of 18-electron half-Heusler compounds using first-principles calculations.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2013-04-01|title=Prediction of topological insulating behavior in inverse Heusler compounds from first principles|journal=Computational Materials Science|language=en|volume=70|pages=145–149|doi=10.1016/j.commatsci.2012.12.013|issn=0927-0256|last1=Zhang|first1=X.M.|last2=Liu|first2=E.K.|last3=Liu|first3=Z.Y.|last4=Liu|first4=G.D.|last5=Wu|first5=G.H.|last6=Wang|first6=W.H.|arxiv=1210.5816|s2cid=53506226}}</ref> These materials have not yet shown any sign of intrinsic topological insulator behavior in actual experiments.
